newsitem.title: CAMBODIA: Cambodian PM says Thai army pressuring Khmer Rouge.
newsitem.headline: Cambodian PM says Thai army pressuring Khmer Rouge.

text.p: Cambodian co-Premier Prince Norodom Ranariddh said on Tuesday his government was working with the Thai army to pressure dwindling Khmer Rouge hardliners to defect to the Cambodian military.

But Ranariddh said he would not allow the Cambodian military to attack the last of the Khmer Rouge guerrillas, the architects of the brutal 1975-1979 "killing fields" regime under the leadership of Pol Pot.
The rebels, numbering fewer than 2,000 following a wave of recent defections, are holed up at their northwest base of Anlong Veng near the Thai border.
In an interview with Reuters, Ranariddh said the Thai army was working with Cambodian officials to convince hardliners, including the infamous one-legged commander Ta Mok, to defect.
"We are dealing directly with the royal Thai army," he said.
The Khmer Rouge, whose rule left more than one million Cambodians dead from murder, overwork, disease or malnutrition, have been weakened by thousands of defections since August.
The Maoist guerrillas signed a 1991 peace pact but later reneged on the deal and have been fighting the coalition government which came to power after U.N.-sponsored elections in 1993.
